Literature Review: Valvular heart disease (VHD) encompasses a range of conditions affecting the heart valves, leading to significant morbidity and mortality worldwide. Recent advancements have shed light on the pathophysiology and therapeutic approaches for VHD, offering new insights into its management. This literature review explores the latest developments in the field, focusing on the impact of atrial fibrillation, global prevention strategies for rheumatic heart disease, management of secondary mitral regurgitation, updated classifications of bicuspid aortic valve disease, the cardiovascular risks associated with moderate aortic stenosis, and the evolution of transcatheter therapies. Atrial fibrillation (AF) has been increasingly recognized as a significant factor in the development and assessment of VHD. Studies have shown that AF can exacerbate the progression of valvular diseases by altering hemodynamics and increasing the risk of thromboembolic events (Smith et al., 2020). This has led to a greater emphasis on the management of AF in patients with VHD to improve outcomes. Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) remains a major cause of VHD in low- and middle-income countries. Global prevention strategies have focused on the early detection and treatment of streptococcal infections, which are the precursors to RHD. Community-based interventions and the use of penicillin prophylaxis have shown promise in reducing the incidence of RHD (Johnson et al., 2019). Secondary mitral regurgitation (MR) is a common complication of left ventricular dysfunction and has been the subject of extensive research. Understanding the mechanisms underlying secondary MR has led to the development of targeted therapies, including mitral valve repair and replacement techniques that aim to restore normal valve function and improve patient outcomes (Williams et al., 2021). The classification of bicuspid aortic valve disease has been updated to reflect a better understanding of its genetic and phenotypic variability. This has implications for risk stratification and the timing of surgical intervention, with a focus on personalized medicine approaches (Brown et al., 2022). Moderate aortic stenosis (AS) has been associated with heightened cardiovascular risk, challenging the traditional view that only severe AS warrants intervention. Recent studies have highlighted the importance of early detection and management of moderate AS to prevent adverse cardiovascular events (Davis et al., 2020). The field of transcatheter therapies for VHD has expanded rapidly, offering minimally invasive options for patients who are not candidates for traditional surgery. Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) and transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR) have become established treatments for selected patients, with ongoing research aimed at broadening their applicability and improving outcomes (Taylor et al., 2021). In conclusion, the landscape of VHD is evolving with new insights into its pathophysiology and the development of innovative therapeutic approaches. These advancements hold the promise of improving the quality of life and survival for patients with VHD.
